item.description: Keywords changed

duplicate:

Duplicate of #1591

item.title: Ticket #1591 (The difference in $_SERVER['PATH_INFO']) reopened
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
This is still the problem. this was my solution: 

if ( strpos($_SERVER['SCRIPT_FILENAME'], 'php.cgi') == strlen($_SERVER['SCRIPT_FILENAME']) - 7 )
	$_SERVER['SCRIPT_FILENAME'] = $_SERVER['PATH_TRANSLATED'];
if ( $_SERVER['PATH_INFO'] == $_SERVER['PHP_SELF'] )
	unset($_SERVER['PATH_INFO']);

Fixes two problems with PHP as CGI on Dreamhost.

item.title: Ticket #1825 (Display a User's Role in profile.php and user-edit.php) updated
item.dc:creator: MichaelH
item.description:
With the patch installed, you can change a User's Role in user-edit.php, but you are allowed to "demote" yourself from being an administrator. As mentioned in ​Ticket 1645, the User should not be able to subtract edit_users capability from themselves.

To promote a user to administrator (that should kill ringmaster P) using phpMyAdmin, change wp_metauser for the user_id:

wp_capabilites to: a:1:{s:13:"administrator";b:1;} and wp_user_level to: 10

davidhouse: your patch does more than I asked for! Thanks.

item.title: Ticket #1832 (Permalink setup does not escape "." in .htaccess) created
item.dc:creator: erikcw
item.description:
When setting up permalinks in admin, WP does not escape "." in .htaccess.

Example:

Permalink

/%category%/%post_title%.%post_id%

All occurrences of "." in the .htaccess mod-rewrite regular expression must be escaped ("\.") or else mod-rewrite treats them as port of the expression. This generates a 404 error.

item.title: Ticket #1645 (You can deactivate the only administrator!) updated
item.dc:creator: ringmaster
item.description:
Keywords changed

It's difficult to say "Administrator" when dealing with capabilities, since the names of the roles are arbitrary.

Instead, this patch prevents a user from selecting a role for themselves that does not have the edit_users capability.

To test, add this line to the bottom of your admin-footer.php, which will grant the "Editor" role with edit_users permissions:

<?php $wp_roles->add_cap('editor', 'edit_users'); ?>

item.title: Ticket #1823 (A newly registered user (or Added User) is assigned "inactive" and ...) updated
item.dc:creator: MichaelH
item.description:
When a new user is added here's what wp_usermeta has: 

wpbz_capabilities:  a:1:{s:8:"inactive";b:1;}
wpbz_user_level:  0

Then when you Set the Role to make Editor; 

wpbz_capabilities:  a:2:{s:8:"inactive";b:1;s:6:"editor";b:1;}
wpbz_user_level:  7

item.title: Ticket #1796 (Session Saver inserts date in Write Post password field) updated
item.dc:creator: nmoog
item.description:
The timestamp input fields do not have ids associated with them (just names). The Session Saver extension fails to match the input boxes because "if we couldn't get by id, we'll blind-guess, hoping to find one as close to the original hierarchy as possible"

Adding an id to the input box fixes this.

item.title: Add_ids_to_timestamp.diff attached to Ticket #1796
item.dc:creator: nmoog

item.title: Ticket #1829 (Assign categories to images) created
item.dc:creator: IoZ
item.description: When we upload an image, it will be nice the ability to assign them to categories. Currently, images are automatically assigned to "General" category. I think that now this is more easy to implement, because images are "object" posts. Another good option will be create a new section to manage "object" posts.

item.title: Ticket #1828 (There are some bugs in flickr image browser pagination) updated

item.title: Ticket #1516 (<blockquote> and <!--more-->) closed
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
duplicate:

As noted before, this is a duplicate of #178.

But I still contend that the ability to balance a post regardless of where the <!--more--> is inserted would be a user-friendly way of dealing with things. My patch to #178 (which I'm sure needs updating to apply to the latest code) demonstrated it is possible with minimal code changes or overhead.

However, prevailing winds suggest this may not be implemented. Reopen #178 and make your case to the dev team if you feel strongly about the matter.

item.title: Ticket #1823 (A newly registered user (or Added User) is assigned "inactive" and ...) updated
item.dc:creator: MichaelH
item.description: Summary changed

item.title: Ticket #1823 (A newly registered user (or Added User) is assigned "inactive" and ...) created
item.dc:creator: MichaelH
item.description:
A newly registered user (or Added User) is assigned "inactive" and displays at the bottom of the User List by Role of Users.

The user-edit.php shows "Additional Capabilities: inactive" for the new registrant.

Interestingly, only "inactive" users show "Additional Capabilites:" in user-edit.php.

You can not Set the Role for this new user either.

Isn't this really a reflection of the fact there is no way to officially set what capability (or is it role) is assigned new users?

item.title: Ticket #1822 (double email notification) created
item.dc:creator: danhash
item.description: if comment moderation email notices are on AND comment email notices are one, you will get an email asking you to moderate the comment, and once you approve it you will get ANOTHER email telling you about the comment you just approved.

item.title: Ticket #1668 (pingback xml format is false) updated
item.dc:creator: masquerade
item.description:
Keywords changed

I'll chime in and say that this is the proper fix, last arg being an array causes IXR_Value to go recursive and output the <array> and such tags. ​http://www.hixie.ch/specs/pingback/pingback-1.0#send is the important bit of the Pingback specification, it expects two args, and instead WP would be passing 1 arg as an array with the 2 args it should be sending seperately

item.title: Ticket #1821 (Is WordPress available in unzipped file?-> Answer) closed
item.dc:creator: Potter_System
item.description:
invalid:

WordPress has more than 150 files inside, so at this moment the best way for get it is using ZIP or TAR files.

If you are using Windows XP, open the file with the integrated Windows unzipper (right clic in WordPress ZIP file, go to Open with and search for "zip" beside the other program; I don't have English Windows to tell you exactly where to clic)

And please, next time go to WordPress Forums.

item.title: Ticket #1819 (extra <a href="http://www.LINK.org" /> links "Posted in") created
item.dc:creator: carnaticwm
item.description:
please do the following - i could reproduce the issue at kishore.wordpress.com as well as a local install

1) write post

2) title: testing

3) body:

3-a) type: kishore

3-b) mark: kishore

3-c) click on "insert/edit link"

3-d) for the url, enter: ​http://www.kishore.org

3-d) press END ( to reach end of word )

-> you are now at next line

3-e) type: kishore1

3-f) publish

EDIT the entry and see the html -> it contains 

<p><a href="http://www.kishore.org">kishore.org</a></p>
<p>kishore </p>
<a href="http://www.kishore.org" />

the third line is unexpected and seems to be a bug !

item.title: Ticket #1593 (Fixing the "From" address on all emails.) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Bah, you're right. I'll work on a patch. Thanks.

item.title: Ticket #1818 (A not-closed <a> tag does not get corrected in comments) created
item.dc:creator: tjaard
item.description: Today I got a comment on my blog and the person who wrote the comment did not completely understand the <a> tag, forgetting to close it. WP did not correct this, leading to a yellow screen because of malformed XML (I serve XHTML with the correct mime type). Even if standard WP installations use text/html and therefore the user won't get parse errors, it is not acceptable that ordinary visitors can screw up a blog's markup, as using text/html as a mime type will probably still show the remaining text of the blog as a link.

item.title: Ticket #1810 (Comment Mass Edit mode should use AJAX) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description: Keywords changed

item.title: Ticket #1593 (Fixing the "From" address on all emails.) reopened
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
I'm not convinced this is fixed so reopening.

wp_notify_postauthor in ​trunk/wp-includes/pluggable-functions.php calls wp_mail() with a non-blank headers which includes already a From: line with the commenters email address in it: 

        if ('' == $comment->comment_author_email || '' == $comment->comment_author) {
                $from = "From: \"$blogname\" <wordpress@" . $_SERVER['SERVER_NAME'] . '>';
        } else {
                $from = 'From: "' . $comment->comment_author . "\" <$comment->comment_author_email>";
        }
        $message_headers = "MIME-Version: 1.0\n"
                . "$from\n"
                . "Content-Type: text/plain; charset=\"" . get_settings('blog_charset') . "\"\n";

item.title: Ticket #1817 (Protection against multiple trackbacks in one bunch) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
When processing Trackbacks, duplicates are not eliminated.

Patch adds pinged URIs to in-hand copy of pinged URIs as they are pinged, so that there can be no duplicate pings.

Thanks to Kamigoroshi for pointing out this bug in #wordpress to me

item.title: Ticket #1816 (Link Category before/after settings nonfunctional) created
item.dc:creator: Dachannien
item.description:
There are settings in the site admin panel (Links/Link Categories) for code to insert before and after each link as well as between the link and the description. While the option is properly inserted into the database, it is never used by get_links_list() in wp-includes/links.php .

The solution is simple - modify the db query in get_links_list() to ask for the three additional fields: 

$cats = $wpdb->get_results("
            SELECT DISTINCT link_category, cat_name, show_images,
            show_description, show_rating, show_updated, sort_order,
            sort_desc, list_limit,
            text_before_link, text_after_link, text_after_all
            FROM `$wpdb->links`  ...

and then use those values in the call to get_links: 

            get_links($cat['link_category'],
                 $cat['text_before_link'],
                 $cat['text_after_all'],
                 $cat['text_after_link'],   ...

item.title: Ticket #1690 (change to admin/post.php template after post has been created) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith

Keywords, Owner, Status changed

item.title: Ticket #993 (Post pings itself on updating) updated

item.description: Status changed

item.title: Ticket #993 (Post pings itself on updating) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Owner, Status changed

item.title: Ticket #993 (Post pings itself on updating) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Keywords, Milestone changed

Patch prevents this on both ends.

When sending Pingbacks, it will not send a Pingback to itself.

When receiving Pingbacks, it will not register a Pingback from itself. (Lest a crapflooder use this to make every entry on someone's blog ping itself to cause mischief.)

item.title: no-self-ping.diff attached to Ticket #993
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Patch for WP 1.6 SVN

item.title: Ticket #1814 (Trackbacks do not send correct permalinks) created
item.dc:creator: nilsjeppe
item.description: It seems that trackbacks send "messy" URLs and not the correct permalinks. Needless to say, this is not such a great idea, especially since one can hardly change trackbacks after they have been sent. Yes, it still works, but it's absolutely unclean, and it may break compatibility if I change my software in the future but keep my URL layout (the "permanent" part of Permalinks).
